content: You lean back in your seat and sigh, listening to the constant hum of the plane and the gentle rumble underneath you as you gaze out the window. What to do now?

content: You turn your head and meet the other person's gaze. Said person's face blooms red as they turn and cough into their hand. "Apologies," they said. "It's just - aren't you Dr. Banks?"

content:
You manage a polite smile. "Sorry, you must have the wrong person.".

"Oh! I'm so sorry! I thought - never mind, I'll leave you alone then." Flushing and shifting uncomfortably in their seat, they turn to look out the window.

"Oh, of course! Sorry!" they say, somehow unfazed by the rudeness of the question. "I'm Daniel Schmit, nice to meet you! I saw your talk the other day - you were {ifStateCondition|confidence gte 5|quite wonderful! I mean, you certainly seemed nicer back then...|rather interesting. I guessed you were nervous, but maybe my first impression was wrong...}"

choiceLabel: You turn to talk to the person who's leaning very, very close to you.
content:
Your first instinct is to lean away from the long nose inching closer to the newspaper lying in your lap. "Um," you say. Their head jerks up.

"Oh. Hey." They jab at the paper. "'Global Warming Is At An All Time High'. Funny, huh?"

choiceLabel: I don't see how global warming's funny.
content: Their eyebrows furrow. "Oh, you're one of those people, are you? Don't worry, dear, it was pretty cold this year round. Spring came late again and everything, so the cold weather's lasting longer."

choiceLabel: Tell them about why global warming is legitimate.
content:
"You see, there's a difference between weather and climate," you explain {ifStateCondition|confidence gte 5|patiently.|with a hint of frustration.} "Even if it's pretty cold in one area, the global temperature has been proven by science to be slowly rising. Which causes problems all over the world."
Your fellow passenger looks thoughtful. "Huh," They say.
"If you say so," you sigh as you gaze out the window. The logical fallacies in the statement is itching at you, but you've decided to stay silent.

They blink. "Well, you know," they say. "People always say 'global warming, how horrible!' but after a while you have to wonder if it's all bologne. Like, my mother would always say it's a some government conspiracy, but she was a conspiracy nut. Me, I always wonder whenever the weather gets really cold, you know? That's what science is, isn't it - questioning things?

choiceLabel: Chat with the friendly-looking person sitting next to you.
content: Their smile reaches their eyes as they respond to you, and you can't help but feel the tension drain out of your shoulders as the conversation continues pleasantly. You almost forget about your worries as you approach your destination.

choiceLabel: Read the newspaper folded in your lap.
content: You pick up the paper. It crinkles pleasantly in your hands as you flip it over and let it fall open under your fingers.

You unfold the newspaper and scan the headlines. {ifStateCondition|fame gte 5|You find yourself on the front page, much to your surprise and delight.|You find a little snippet about your talk later in the news.} {ifStateCondition|confidence gte 5|The article gushes over your poise and intellect, and you can't help but smile, your face flushed.|The article wasn't very kind, but you're not surprised. You were painfully aware of how well you did there.}

content: Your favorite grassroots environmental organization has sent you your weekly newsletter.

You grab your carry-ons and follow the line of people off the plane, thanking the pilot on the way out. It feels so good to stretch your legs after hours curled up in a plane seat.
